title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges misconduct, bias, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers by the panel that materially affected the decision, they can file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. Parties can file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade within 30 days if they allege misconduct, bias, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers by the panel that affected the decision. The Court will examine the legal and factual analysis of the panel's decision and determine if any actions have been established, vacating or affirming the original panel decision accordingly. The Court's decisions are binding on the parties involved. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. Parties can file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade within 30 days if they allege misconduct, bias, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers by the panel that affected the decision. The Court will examine the legal and factual analysis of the panel's decision and determine if any actions have been established, vacating or affirming the original panel decision accordingly. The Court's decisions are binding on the parties involved. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. "Sec. 404A. Review of binational panel determinations. SEC. 3. JURISDICTION OF THE COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE." Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include provisions related to binational panel determinations under NAFTA. This includes adding a final determination of a binational panel convened pursuant to article 1904 of the NAFTA. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include provisions for binational panel determinations under NAFTA, including final determinations requested by a party or person under article 1904. The amendments made by this Act apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA published in the Federal Register after the enactment date.
